case_vignette: A 75-year-old woman presents with sudden loss of vision. She says that she was reading when suddenly she was not able to see the print on half of the page. Her symptoms started 4 hours ago and are accompanied by a severe posterior headache. Vital signs reveal the following: blood pressure 119/76 mm Hg, pulse 89/min, SpO2 98% on room air. The patient was unable to recognize her niece when she arrived to see her. A noncontrast CT of the head shows no evidence of hemorrhagic stroke.
question: What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I suddenly lost my vision while reading, and I can't see the print on half of the page.
Have you had any similar symptoms before?
No, this is the first time this has happened to me.
Have you noticed any other changes in your vision, such as blurriness or double vision?
No, just the sudden loss of vision on one side while I was reading.
Have you had any recent headaches or dizziness?
Yes, I'm experiencing a severe headache at the back of my head.
Have you had any recent changes in your medication or diet?
The case vignette doesn't provide information about changes in medication or diet.
Have you had any recent changes in your lifestyle, such as increased stress or lack of sleep?
The case vignette doesn't provide information about lifestyle changes such as increased stress or lack of sleep.
Have you had any family history of eye conditions or neurological disorders?
The case vignette doesn't provide information about family history of eye conditions or neurological disorders.
Final Diagnosis: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
